ratings.comment: Lisa was rude and unhelpful throughout the semester. She delighted in pointing out when someone asked a dumb question. That being said, she gives a LOT of extra credit opportunities that make it much easier to pass. If you have a TA who isn't strict you should be okay in this class. It's necessary to go to all lectures/get notes from a friend.

If you love Medieval Literature this is the class for you. If you're just an English major trying to fulfill your requirements, take another professor. Prof. Cooper is passionate about what she teaches but with expert blindness, her class is incredibly difficult. The whole class is graded on 4 assignments so you can't mess up either.

I don't know what is wrong with this women but something definitely is. I didn't mind her class, it was boring and monotonous, but what really made me angry was Professor Cooper. This woman just loves the sound of her own voice and will talk about things that have nothing to do with the class. Wouldn't be surprised if she was diagnosed narcissist.

Don't take if you aren't an English major. If you need a lit and ethnic req, take asian am/engl 462. The final is on all material, the tests are completely write in and identify passages and then write an essay about them. Old English is like learning a new language. Cooper loves what she teaches and is kind, but this class is just hard material.

This class is very dense in material, but grading criteria is clear in her extensive syllabus. Cooper knows a lot about medieval drama and will make class engaging, despite the readings being a bit of a bore sometimes. The final performance, while a lot of work, was also highly rewarding and enjoyable. Attend every class to understand material.

Cooper is very smart and super knowledgeable in her field. If you pay attention in lecture, you learn a lot. That being said, discussion was sometimes downright uncomfortable: she has a very specific idea of what is right, and will not hesitate to tear apart someone's comment if she doesn't agree with it. There is also an insane workload.

Professor Cooper is very enthusiastic about the material. That being said, the material is very dense; it is hard to read because the plays are all in old English without modern translations. She is very anti-Technology so don't even try to bring a laptop. You have to write a final paper but she does not give writing feed back all semester.

This class has a lot of reading and writing. Although there are no tests, we had to put on a medieval performance and write a 10-12 theatrical review. The readings are dense and somewhat difficult to understand for a three-credit class. She has high expectations, but that is expected with an upper-level course.

Cooper's style of teaching is very old-school. Be prepared to read a ton every week. She does not like Canvas so you will not know your overall grade or grades on assignments unless you get a meeting with her. Classes feel extremely long and are usually entirely lecture/discussion. You will get in trouble if you are seen with phones or laptops.

Dr. Cooper is fantastic, one of the knowledgeable and most charismatic English professors I've had. She makes every class enjoyable and informative, even when it's mostly discussion. She pushes you just the right amount and is very fair about readings and grades. Highly recommend!

Professor Cooper is a really good lecturer. I enjoyed the class a lot. Attending every lecture is important and taking notes on what she says than what's just on the slides is just as important. Large portion of the exams are heavily reliant on what she said in lecture, so attending every class is a must. If you skip a class make sure to follow up.

Cooper is a great professor and made the material very engaging. I really enjoyed the class. My only con is she didn't make what to study for the exams clear. Part of the exams are heavily reliant on the lectures and taking notes on what she says in lecture than what's just on the slides is important - which makes attending every lecture crucial.

Cooper is a good prof overall - she's strict though. No wiggle room on the syllabus and she has some rules like no taking notes on computers which don't make a lot of sense. She is very passionate about the literature she teaches and gives great analyses of the work which makes lectures interesting, but she's not super personable. TAs grade papers.

I love Professor Cooper! She's very organized and knowledgeable about the material. Make sure to attend every lecture; she doesn't post her slides. There is plenty of extra credit offered to ensure a descent grade. She's uncompromising on anything outlined in the lengthy syllabus, but I appreciated the clear expectations.

Graded by 2 papers, 2 exams, and discussion participation. A bad paper could sink your grade irreversibly. I am not a fan of middle english stuff, but the professor's energy did make it slightly bearable. However, miss even one lecture (2x/wk) and expect to lose points on the exam. Write down nearly EVERYTHING she says, lecture slides are very bare

She makes a boring subject way more interesting. Lots of extra credit opportunities. Would not say its easy in terms of papers but if you go to lecture, exams are easy. Lecture attendance is not taken but you need to go to do well. Discussion attendance also required. Def take if you like middle english, I don't but still found it okay/

Professor Cooper is a renowned researcher in the matters of literary tradition and Old/Middle English. She raises fascinating points in lecture about assigned readings, and anyone can tell she's passionate about the content. However, she's very strict about electronic use and students whispering in lecture. Follow her rules or be singled out.

Professor Cooper is very passionate about what she teaches. Although she can come off as a bit strict at times, I respect her a lot and greatly enjoy her lectures. She makes the material interesting, and helps quite a bit for comprehension, as a lot of it is dense reading in Middle/Old English.

Professor Cooper is an amazing lecturer and teaches 241 very well. I expected to be very bored by the topics and literature but was pleasantly surprised. Exams are completely lecture-based, so make sure you show up to lecture. She is very strict on discussion attendance, which is understandable. She does come off as a bit unapproachable.

Exams rely heavily on small details outlined in lectures that you must attend (as lecture notes are not posted on Canvas), but there are a lot of extra credit opportunities which are very helpful. Professor Cooper does come off as intimidating and can be hard to approach.

Exams are all lecture-based, as long as you show up to class and take good notes you will be fine. There is also a ton of extra credit offered which is helpful. Professor Cooper is a great lecturer but comes off a bit intimidating and unapproachable which is the only reason I gave her a 4 and not a 5.

Prof Cooper is more focused on standing in your way of a good grade than she is helping you toward one. Lectures were purposely obscured in order to force out of class studying and Cooper made sure to create a dismal atmosphere in each class with her naggy tone. One misstep in this class is all it takes to sink your grade. Do not take,

Professor Cooper really knows her stuff; you won't be let down if you're thoroughly interested in Old and Middle English. But, if you're like me and find those subjects boring as hell, this class will kinda suck. The lectures are incredibly dense. She brings a little energy to the room, but not enough for the material to be interesting.

Professor Cooper seems intimidating and serious at first, but I soon learned that she is super friendly and caring. She makes lectures fun to attend. The exams are very easy. Half of it is based on terms or ideas she mentioned in class, and it's easy to create a quizlet to study. Middle English lit can be boring, but she made it fun and engaging.

Dr. Cooper is a fantastic educator. I was wary at first because she sent six emails before the first day of class and seemed like a hardass on the first day. But she really provides all the resources necessary and makes herself available. Her exams are pretty hard, but she does a fair amount of prep. I'm really glad I took this class.

Medieval lit can be tough but Prof. Cooper cares so much it is fun. She is energetic, caring, and connects our reading to the modern world. There are two exams and two essays, none of which are super hard. There is so much extra credit for exams you have to try to not get an A. Lectures are not posted online so you really need to be there.

Attendance isn't mandatory but she doesn't post lectures online, and half of the midterm and the final exam is just basically very specific details she mentions about the books during lecture. The exams are also very difficult and specific. Usually, I do very well in English classes but this one was rough! Don't take this unless you love Chaucer.

Chaucer is no cakewalk but Prof. Cooper brings such enthusiasm to class that it is contagious. She is strict but simply wants her students to experience the rewards of learning to read middle English. Much of what you learn will be guided by where you and your classmates direct discussion, so participation is key.

Awesome class!  It's a little more tough than other English courses, but as long as you show up to lecture, take good notes, and do the reading, it isn't hard to get an A.  Plus, lectures are interesting.  I never found myself bored or daydreaming.  I would absolutely take another class with professor Cooper.

Cooper is fantastic. Especially at a huge research university, it's  amazing to have a professor that truly wants you to succeed, that is, if you do the work. A lot of reading that can be hard but she presents it in a really compelling way. Go to her office hours, she'll appreciate that. Go  more than once. 2 papers, one midterm and a final.

Class seems intimidating at first but really isn't that bad. Go to lecture to get the attendance credit, it will really help your grade. I got an AB but my course work was probably only a B.  Prof. Cooper does a good job explaining a lot of tough materiel.

If you are the type of person who went to college because you ACTUALLY want and like to learn, Cooper is an awesome prof. I really enjoyed her lectures and learned a lot from her. If you hate going to class and don't really want to learn or put forth any effort, don't take this class with her. If you are interested at all in English, she's great!

Fantastic professor. Although she comes off as a bit intimidating due to her brilliance on the subject, she relates the material well to students by providing relatable examples. Attendance is mandatory-must sign in to lectures. Attendance overall is worth 30% of your grade, which brings grade up if you attend. Easily my favorite power lecture.

She does a very good job of relating the material to the class but has a problem with getting side-tracked. Sometimes she thinks lecture is her stand-up comedy hour, which slows down the process. Many times she won't get through all of the material for the day. That said, her passion for middle English makes the class fairly interesting.

TA makes or breaks your grade. Attendance for discussion & lecture are mandatory but make up a HUGE part of your final grade. She had exam reviews in class and split the class into teams - fun & competitive. I learned a lot and I liked the reading selections. It was my favorite of the "core" 4 credit English classes I had to take.

Prof. Cooper is an expert in her field. Don't be uninterested from taking this class - Medieval Romance is really stories of King Arthur. Fantastic class & is discussion based. Helpful & approachable in office hours. Attendance is mandatory but provides a boost for your grade at the end. The reading amount is decent. One of the best classes I've ha

Love her! At first she comes off as abrasive and strict. But she's wonderful once you've had a few lectures. She explains things I would never understand on my own in a way that is clear and engaging. I always WANTED to go to class. She is the best lecturer I've had so far.

Has a mandatory attendance policy that really boosts your grade at the end of the semester. Can be a bit intimidating, but is incredibly passionate about the texts. I would take another class from her for sure!
She's a really great professor. I would definitely recommend her! Her lectures are engaging and really help make some not so engaging texts more interesting.

Cooper was great, funny and engaging, I love her and would gladly take another class with her. Many people complain about mandatory attendance but it's an easy grade boost, and with most lit classes attendance should be mandatory anyway. I would recommend her to anyone.

Attendance is mandatory but offers a huge grade boost at semester's end. Notetaking from her powerpoints can be difficult but if you understand the big ideas and read the material, you will be ok. Cooper can be intimidating, but she once you get past this you can see that she is a true expert in the field and passionate about what she teaches.

She is very strict on attendance, but the lectures are very engaging. One thing I didn't like was that her slides are strictly line references, and sometimes historical references. I had difficulty copying the notes and simultaneously listening to her discuss the importance of each line reference.

Don't complain about the attendance policy. If you go to class, it will save your grade. Tests are pretty hard. Memorize everything. Cooper is pretty engaging, and though she can come off as mean, she's actually pretty funny, nice, and approachable. Grades are completely up to TA, so hope for a good one-close read like your life depends on it.

Professor Cooper is entertaining to watch at the podium because she has a strong sense of pride, an engaging lecture style, and a voice that commands attention. The only problem with her lectures would be that although they make sense, they often aren't linear and are hard to take notes on.

I'm not a huge fan of Chaucer...but I really like this class.  It's the only power lecture I have that I'm surprised when it's suddenly over.  Cooper is a smart woman and has a great sense of humor as long as you don't take yourself too seriously.  I'd love to take another class with her.
Best Professor I had in 4 years.  She's truly remarkable - one of the most brilliant people I've ever had the pleasure of knowing.  Just study hard and you'll be fine.

Prof. Cooper's powerpoint lectures were knowledgable and helpful. She uses lots of page and line references and then verbally elaborates. If you take good notes they will be incredibly helpful. She is at times obnoxious and self-righteous but overall gives you all the materials needed for her 2 exams and 3 papers.

Great professor--really gets down and dirty with the text and makes you think about what you read. She can lecture a bit quickly and doesn't post her notes online. Attendance is mandatory, but it's an easy 20% of your grade. 1 midterm, 1 final--fair and not unexpected. She can be intimidating during lecture, but very approachable outside of class.

Her Canterbury Tales class was one of my favorite classes taken at the UW. Not only was she able to make the material relevant, but every lecture was enjoyable to go to. She was also always very helpful during her office hours.

Lisa is one of the best professors I have had at this school. Highly intelligent, interesting, and helpful. Her extent of knowledge really added to the understanding of class material and topics. In learning anything medieval I highly recommend her.
Wow! Blew me away! I was pleasantly surprised by this medieval stuff.
